misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay linked when one array is sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array also rearranges the corresponding names automatically, so the highest score will still line up with the correct student name at the same index.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(z)` only reorders the elements inside `z`. The `names` array `y` is a completely separate array, and Java will not “carry along” related elements from other arrays. To keep names and scores aligned, the program must swap elements in both arrays together during sorting, or use a single combined structure (e.g., an array of objects or pairs) and sort that.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the last name entered (y[n-1]) paired with the highest score (z[n-1]), which may refer to different students after sorting.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array (scores) will automatically keep the parallel array (names) synchronized with the original pairing relationships, such that names[i] still corresponds to scores[i] after the sort.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort() only sorts the array it is called on. When you sort the scores array, the names array is not automatically reordered to match. The correspondence between names[i] and scores[i] is broken. The student has a mental model where arrays are 'linked' or 'move together,' but in reality, they are independent data structures. After sorting scores alone, y[n-1] still refers to the last name entered (Charlie), while z[n-1] now refers to the highest score (92, which belonged to Bob). This causes a mismatch.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the program will print the name of the last student entered paired with the highest score, rather than the correct student name with the highest score (e.g., 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)').

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that arrays created to store related data (parallel arrays) are inherently linked by the runtime such that sorting one array automatically reorders the elements of the other array to preserve the original index-based relationships.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent memory structures. A operation like Arrays.sort() performed on one array has no side effects on any other array. To maintain the relationship in parallel arrays, the programmer must manually swap elements in both arrays during a sort, or use an object-oriented approach.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting changes “paired” parallel arrays together automatically
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will also rearrange the names array in the same way, so the name at index n-1 will still correspond to the highest score after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(z)` only permutes the elements of `z`. It does not know that `y` is a parallel array that must be permuted in the same way. After sorting, indices in `y` and `z` no longer represent the same student unless you explicitly swap elements in both arrays during the sort (or use an array of objects/pairs).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed name may not match the printed top score (name-score association is broken).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array position means “top student” regardless of sorting effects on other arrays
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the last element of the names array (`y[n-1]`) will represent the top student once the scores are sorted, even though they never changed the names array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Index `n-1` in `y` is simply “the last name entered,” not “the name associated with the maximum score.” Sorting `z` does make `z[n-1]` the maximum score, but `y[n-1]` remains whatever was read last. To find the top student you must either (a) track the max score index before sorting, or (b) sort both arrays in sync, or (c) store name+score together and sort those objects.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: frequently prints the last-entered name with the maximum score from a different student.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they call `Arrays.sort(z)` on the scores array, the corresponding names in the parallel `names` array will automatically reorganize to stay paired with their original scores. They think the sorting operation maintains the index-based relationship between the two arrays.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has misunderstood how sorting works with parallel arrays. In reality, `Arrays.sort(z)` only sorts the `z` array in place; it does NOT reorder elements in the `y` array. After sorting `z`, the original pairing between `y[i]` and `z[i]` is destroyed. For example, after sorting: `z = [78, 85, 92]` but `y = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]` (unchanged). So `y[2]` is still "Charlie" even though `z[2]` is now 92 (which belonged to Bob originally). The student needs to understand that parallel arrays must be sorted in tandem (e.g., by swapping elements in both arrays simultaneously) or by using indices to track the correspondence.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)' because it prints the last element of the unsorted names array paired with the last element of the sorted scores array.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array in a parallel array pair automatically rearranges the corresponding elements in the other array to maintain the index-based relationship between names and scores.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java execution model, parallel arrays are independent objects with no inherent link. Using Arrays.sort() on a single array only reorders that specific memory block; it has no side effects on other arrays that the programmer conceptually associates with it. The 'link' between y[i] and z[i] is purely a result of the programmer's logic during input and must be manually maintained during any data transformation.
